Package ssh
[frames] | no frames]

Package ssh

source code

'ssh' is a module for python 2.3 or greater that implements the SSH2 protocol for secure (encrypted and authenticated) connections to remote machines. Unlike SSL (aka TLS), the SSH2 protocol does not require hierarchical certificates signed by a powerful central authority. You may know SSH2 as the protocol that replaced telnet and rsh for secure access to remote shells, but the protocol also includes the ability to open arbitrary channels to remote services across an encrypted tunnel. (This is how sftp works, for example.)

The high-level client API starts with creation of an SSHClient object. For more direct control, pass a socket (or socket-like object) to a Transport, and use start_server or start_client to negoatite with the remote host as either a server or client. As a client, you are responsible for authenticating using a password or private key, and checking the server's host key. (Key signature and verification is done by ssh, but you will need to provide private keys and check that the content of a public key matches what you expected to see.) As a server, you are responsible for deciding which users, passwords, and keys to allow, and what kind of channels to allow.

Once you have finished, either side may request flow-controlled Channels to the other side, which are python objects that act like sockets, but send and receive data over the encrypted session.

'ssh' is written entirely in python (no C or platform-dependent code) and is released under the GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL).

Website: http://www.lag.net/ssh/

Version: 1.7.8

Author: Jeff Forcier

Contact: jeff@bitprophet.org

License: GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL)

Date: 23 October 2011

Submodules
  • ssh.agent: SSH Agent interface for Unix clients.
  • ssh.auth_handler: AuthHandler
  • ssh.ber
  • ssh.buffered_pipe: Attempt to generalize the "feeder" part of a Channel: an object which can be read from and closed, but is reading from a buffer fed by another thread.
  • ssh.channel: Abstraction for an SSH2 channel.
  • ssh.client: SSHClient.
  • ssh.common: Common constants and global variables.
  • ssh.compress: Compression implementations for a Transport.
  • ssh.config: SSHConfig.
  • ssh.dsskey: DSSKey
  • ssh.file: BufferedFile.
  • ssh.hostkeys: HostKeys
  • ssh.kex_gex: Variant on KexGroup1 where the prime "p" and generator "g" are provided by the server.
  • ssh.kex_group1: Standard SSH key exchange ("kex" if you wanna sound cool).
  • ssh.logging22: Stub out logging on python < 2.3.
  • ssh.message: Implementation of an SSH2 "message".
  • ssh.packet: Packetizer.
  • ssh.pipe: Abstraction of a one-way pipe where the read end can be used in select().
  • ssh.pkey: Common API for all public keys.
  • ssh.primes: Utility functions for dealing with primes.
  • ssh.resource: Resource manager.
  • ssh.rsakey: RSAKey
  • ssh.server: ServerInterface is an interface to override for server support.
  • ssh.sftp
  • ssh.sftp_attr
  • ssh.sftp_client: Client-mode SFTP support.
  • ssh.sftp_file: SFTPFile
  • ssh.sftp_handle: Abstraction of an SFTP file handle (for server mode).
  • ssh.sftp_server: Server-mode SFTP support.
  • ssh.sftp_si: SFTPServerInterface is an interface to override for SFTP server support.
  • ssh.ssh_exception: Exceptions defined by ssh.
  • ssh.transport: Transport handles the core SSH2 protocol.
  • ssh.util: Useful functions used by the rest of ssh.
  • ssh.win_pageant: Functions for communicating with Pageant, the basic windows ssh agent program.
